page.title: 02ASHDOWN FOREST ECOLOOGY (l)
page.content: The area is one of wet and dry heath- land with streams running into the River Medway. Ditches and banks still show plainly boundaries of former properties and there are signs of the old 17th century Pillow Mounds created by man to breed rabbits. Plant life is confined to those which flourish on sandy soil in a high wind, or which like the more marshy habitat. Wild life is in turn dependent on the shelter and food provided by these plants. There are a few houses with gardens and one or two small farms. The Commoners, i.e. certain local residents have rights to pasture sheep and to use the natural products of the ground, such as dead wood or bracken. A 250 acre Nature Reserve is privately owned but managed by the Sussex Trust for Nature Conservation. This Trust is set up to manage areas of Special
